Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
configure: error: libdb_cxx headers missing, Bitcoin Core requires this library for wallet functionality (--disable-wallet to disable wallet functionality)
that error means to run build.sh again

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we arent end users, are we? we cant expect all the builds to just magically work as things are updated left and right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if things are not building, then figure out how to solve it. if you cant do that, you need to wait the months it takes for builds to automagically work in all configs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to be on the cutting edge means to not get stopped by simple issues, or even complex ones

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Well, I googled about the error, most suggestions were to change the version of berkely db to 4.8 and download it from bitcoin core's ppa. Tried that too. Still didn't work. So asked here

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this error is always happening with the komodo builds, you never saw that before?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: whenever the makefile change, it seems to get all confused. in any case using build.sh is not any magical deep understanding required

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
didn't see this particular error before. I knew to run build.sh again for an error that had `all recursive failed` or something likethat. 
Will run build.sh again next time if I run into build errors üëç

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, any build error, run build.sh

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if still a problem make clean and build.sh, that seems to be needed sometimes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in extreme cases a fresh clone

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so there are three levels of using build.sh if normal make doesnt work

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c are the below statements true?
```md
- The node that broadcasts it's `hex` of the spend transaction receives the funds in the multisig address.
- If both nodes broadcast their `hex` of the spend transaction, which ever transaction confirms first, the corresponding node gets credited with the spend.
```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: neither are true

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well maybe it is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it depends on the details of the spend

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess using the spend rpc, yes it would be the case. but the idea is that all signers will verify the tx that is being signed

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c  Ok. So they are currently true for someone using the RPC.
I am guessing the `calcmsg` RPC will be modified in the future to include a `recipient pubkey`?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you pass in the destination scriptPubKey already

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c as I understand it, the scriptPubKey that is being passed in, belongs to the vout that returns change to the sender. 
And I am not sure how this scriptPubKey is being used right now

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is where the funds are sent

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: that confused me for ages... why it was using the change scriptPubKey ... its the destination of the spennd, took a while to work that one out lol

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i just wanted a scriptPubKey that I would be able to spend

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: doesnt have to be the change

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: can be any scriptPubKey, it is just the destination for funds

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: yes might be a good thing to put in docs. Has anyone tested musig since my PR yesterday?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c what is `pk_hash`?
In the source, I have found
```
pk_hash: The 32-byte hash of the original public keys
```
does that mean the original pubkeys are concatenated and hashed? to get a 32 byte hash?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it identifies a specific set of pubkeys for the in-memory data structure

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Got it.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@jl777c if the signers wanted to spend to <pubkeyA>, the calcmessage method will be:
```
./komodo-cli -ac_name=MUSIG  cclib calcmsg 18 '["sendtxid1","21<<pubkeyA>>ac"]'
 ```
Is that so?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: and they will spend only the amount added through the txid: `sendtxid1`?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will only spend the sendtxid/vout0

Content: can the musig address be funded using the `sendtoaddress` rpc, i.e., convert `combined_pk` to address format and use `sendtoaddress`? @jl777c

Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the musig send must be used

Content: Ok

Content: ultimately such would be possible, but not anytime soon

Content: Got it.

Content:

-  **node1** produces  `nonce12` using `commitment2` from **node2**

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: every node needs every nonce

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: if you know any python look at the `musigtest.py` I think its resasonably easy to follow

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: for each node, it loops all nodes and gives them the nonce it has. same for the next 3 steps

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
so does node2 run both these commands and another 2 with ind:2
```
./komodo-cli -ac_name=MUSIG cclib nonce 18 '["pkhash",0,"nonce produced by n0 using commit from n2"]'
```
and
```
./komodo-cli -ac_name=MUSIG cclib nonce 18 '["pkhash",0,"nonce produced by n0 using commit from n3"]'
```
notice both the above commands have ind: 0

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @blackjok3r ^

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
```i = 0
nonces = []
for pubkey in pubkeys:
    ret = rpc.setpubkey(pubkey)
    n = 0
    for commitment in commitments:
        tmp = str([pkhash, n, commitment, i])
        ret = rpc.cclib("commit", "18", tmp)
        try:
            nonces.append(ret['nonce'])
        except:
            x = 1
        n = n + 1
i = i + 1```

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I think so. each node has to send everything to all other nodes

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: except itself... but for the script I disabled the need to skip yourself. for simplicity
